description: Alternation (due to give) of Middle English foryiven, forȝiven, from Old English forġiefan (“to forgive, to give”), from Proto-Germanic *fragebaną (“to give away; give up; release; forgive”), equivalent to for- +‎ give (etymologically for- + yive). Cognate with Scots forgeve, forgif, forgie (“to forgive”), West Frisian ferjaan (“to forgive”), Dutch vergeven (“to forgive”), German vergeben (“to forgive”), Icelandic fyrirgefa (“to forgive”).

verbs.description: forgive (third-person singular simple present forgives, present participle forgiving, simple past forgave, past participle forgiven)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pardon; to waive any negative feeling or desire for punishment, retribution, or compensation.
examples: Please forgive me if my phone goes off - I'm expecting an urgent call from my boss.
Forgive others, not because they deserve forgiveness, but because you deserve peace.
Forgive a debt, that is, tell a debtor that a repayment of a loan is no longer needed.
The brave know only how to forgive  […] A coward never forgave; it is not in his nature.
